title: Work - same force pulling different blocks

content.question: Two blocks, of masses <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> and <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math>, are initially at rest on a horizontal surface. Friction between the blocks and the surface is negligible. The block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is pulled a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> to the right by a constant horizontal force of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math>. The block of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> is also pulled a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> to the left by a constant horizontal force of the same magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math>. What is the ratio of the work done by the force on the block of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> to the work done by the force on the block of mass <math alttext="2 m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>m</mi></math> ?

skill.text: 2.D: Predict new values or factors of change of physical quantities using functional dependence between variables.
